description: {"blocks":[{"key":"5inor","text":"Brief explanation for how to access, log in, and navigate the research cluster server. Note that this protocol is optimized for Mac users. Windows users will likely need to adjust to running commands in Powershell. See cluster user guide for help: https://collab.ucsd.edu/display/RESUP/UCSD+Research+Cluster%3A+User+Guide","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":248,"length":73}],"data":{}},{"key":"fu3h7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7mcrg","text":"More information about the cluster can be found here: https://blink.ucsd.edu/faculty/instruction/tech-guide/dsmlp/","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":54,"length":60}],"data":{}},{"key":"458l4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cq8pm","text":"Research cluster contact: datahub@ucsd.edu","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c6b50","text":"We also have a contact for more specific/urgent technical help, Alan Moxley (reach out to Marina for contact info).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"5D29A8DA43D111EB9E300A58A9FEAC2A","url":"https://collab.ucsd.edu/display/RESUP/UCSD+Research+Cluster%3A+User+Guide"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"CB65305ACF8E11EB9E260A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://blink.ucsd.edu/faculty/instruction/tech-guide/dsmlp"}}}}

status.info: We use this protocol and it's working

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"b2rq4","text":"Log on to the UCSD VPN with your AD login credentials (Cisco AnyConnect if you're not on UCSD campus Wifi). You will need to be connected to the VPN (or be on UCSD Wifi) in order to access the cluster.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1182c","text":"Your login credentials will be very similar to your AD login credentials/UCSD email. To Log in to the server for the purposes of uploading or downloading files, use the sftp command and your AD login appended by @dsmlp-login.ucsd.edu, then press enter.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":169,"length":4},{"style":"bold","offset":212,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1sopq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ahkgm","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"e9dsm","text":"You will be prompted for a password. Type in your AD password and press enter.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"","data":{"can_edit":1,"command_name":"","description":null,"guid":"47BE91E2341F11EE9D4302C0B41BC903","name":"sftp adlogin@dsmlp-login.ucsd.edu","os_name":null,"os_version":null}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3c9jl","text":"Once you're logged into the server, your automatic working directory will be your home directory (on the server). Use ls to view folders and files in your home directory and cd to navigate in and out of folders as you would on your home computer.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":118,"length":3},{"style":"bold","offset":174,"length":3}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9goju","text":"To upload a file from your computer to the server, use put with the absolute path of your file on your computer (Mac users can click and drag their file into the terminal window to copy the file's absolute path). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":55,"length":3}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ff42j","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8cb3i","text":"You can also use the point-and-click interface available through Jupyter notebooks to upload files (look for a link when you launch a pod; see Section 3). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":155},{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":155}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b7nt8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"76lkk","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"cqth0","text":"If your files are large, they may take some time to upload. Once finished, use ls to double check that your file was uploaded.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":79,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"egnoi","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"","data":{"can_edit":1,"command_name":"","description":null,"guid":"47BE9224341F11EE9D4302C0B41BC903","name":"put absolutepath/to/file/filename","os_name":null,"os_version":null}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"ai3ub","text":"If you are interested in additional information about the cluster, or get stuck and need help, check out the User Guide, available here: https://collab.ucsd.edu/display/RESUP/UCSD+Research+Cluster%3A+User+Guide","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":137,"length":73}],"data":{}},{"key":"5v8l9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c9icc","text":"You can also check the overall status of the cluster here: https://datahub.ucsd.edu/hub/status","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":59,"length":35}],"data":{}},{"key":"eaup","text":"Sometimes it gets very busy at the end of the quarter, so this is a good place to check if you're having issues launching pods due to a lack of available resources. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":165}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"F3F12A4643CF11EB9E300A58A9FEAC2A","url":"https://collab.ucsd.edu/display/RESUP/UCSD+Research+Cluster%3A+User+Guide"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"0DCD891D43D011EB9E300A58A9FEAC2A","url":"https://datahub.ucsd.edu/hub/status"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"c1i8f","text":"Open a terminal window. There are two ways to log on to the server, one for uploading/downloading files, and one for running pods and programs. If you like using Jupyter Notebooks, that is also an option (link available when you launch a pod). Navigate to the following sections according to your needs:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":34,"length":3}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"gdtb","text":"Section 2: Uploading \u0026 Downloading Files (sftp)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8796r","text":"Section 3: Running Pods and Programs (ssh)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5mdop","text":"Section 4: Accessing and Deleting Pods (ssh)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d0ije","text":"Section 5: Checking Progress of Processes (ssh)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d35od","text":"Section 6: Using MitoFinder on the Cluster (ssh)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1j1ri","text":"When you're done uploading files, use the exit command to exit the server.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":42,"length":4}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5qimb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"btl6s","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6uf2t","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":1,"command_name":"","description":null,"guid":"47BE9266341F11EE9D4302C0B41BC903","name":"exit","os_name":null,"os_version":null}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"f0e86","text":"Your login credentials will be very similar to your AD login credentials/UCSD email. To Log in to the server, use the ssh command and your AD login appended by @dsmlp-login.ucsd.edu, then press enter.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":118,"length":3},{"style":"bold","offset":160,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bkgdk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3vjnl","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3hdi7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":1,"command_name":"","description":null,"guid":"47BE92A8341F11EE9D4302C0B41BC903","name":"ssh adlogin@dsmlp-login.ucsd.edu","os_name":null,"os_version":null}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"e8r6c","text":"In order to install and run programs from the command line, you'll need to launch a pod (this allocates cluster resources like cores and memory, to you). The basic command to launch a pod is:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"83psp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"12h5c","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"c7in0","text":"Launching a pod with this command (as is, no arguments) will provide a default allocation of 2 cores and 8 GB of RAM. You can request up to 8 cores and 64GB of RAM for a single pod using the options -c (specify number of cores) and -m (specify GB of RAM). For example, you could launch a pod with maximum resources with the following:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":199,"length":2},{"style":"bold","offset":232,"length":3}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d45t3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e363h","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4kslu","text":"Other detailed options for launching pods are available (see research cluster User Guide: https://collab.ucsd.edu/display/RESUP/UCSD+Research+Cluster%3A+User+Guide#UCSDResearchCluster:UserGuide-LaunchScriptCommandLineOptions)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":90,"length":134}],"data":{}},{"key":"74ikn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":1,"command_name":"","description":null,"guid":"47BE92EA341F11EE9D4302C0B41BC903","name":"launch-scipy-ml.sh","os_name":null,"os_version":null}},"1":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":1,"command_name":"","description":null,"guid":"47BE932B341F11EE9D4302C0B41BC903","name":"launch-scipy-ml.sh -m 64 -c 8","os_name":null,"os_version":null}},"2":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"5C9BF8AA43D911EB9E300A58A9FEAC2A","url":"https://collab.ucsd.edu/display/RESUP/UCSD+Research+Cluster%3A+User+Guide#UCSDResearchCluster:UserGuide-LaunchScriptCommandLineOptions"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5pe3b","text":"JUPYTER NOTEBOOKS","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":17},{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"86v6c","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"15tm7","text":"Once you've launched a pod, you will be provided with a Jupyter Notebooks link. If you're interested in using Jupyter Notebooks, paste the link into your browser. Otherwise all analyses/processes can be run from the command line in your terminal window. Note that you cannot access Jupyter Notebooks upon pod-launch if you're running all your pods \"in the background\" (more on background pods in Step 13).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":254,"length":14},{"style":"italic","offset":274,"length":131}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"206r6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"98ost","text":"Here's an example of what this would look like (link in the box will change every time you launch a pod):","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cpnlq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"oemwo","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"2pujv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"61C88876341F11EE9D4302C0B41BC903","height":214,"id":588089,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"3v0mr\",\"text\":\"Red box shows Jupyter Notebooks Link. Paste this into your browser to use the Jupyter Notebooks interface.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"Screen Shot 2020-12-21 at 2.20.30 PM.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/private/89d0a7e6d776ff27f26f79913cc1fba223efffab0db9ef6d89bc8e2bbb5aee68/ct6fbbujp.png","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/t8j3bbujp.jpg","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/t8j2bbujp.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9s239","text":"IMPORTANT NOTE:  If you do not maintain your connection with the server (e.g. your VPN connection times out, wifi dies, computer goes to sleep, etc), it may interrupt your analysis! ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":15},{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5fbgm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"be9p6","text":"In order to avoid this, you can run launch your pod in the \"background\" with the -b argument. This argument will still allocate the resources you request when you launch your pod, but will run everything in the background, so the system no longer requires a direct connection to your computer (you can disconnect from wifi, shut down your computer, etc and still return later to check on your analysis). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":81,"length":3}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b0ghl","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"dts4j","text":"The above script would launch a pod with 63GB of RAM, 7 cores, and would run in the background, allowing you to interrupt your connection with the server without interrupting any processes you have running on it.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":77,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"86lt0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9bs7d","text":"More information about running pods in the background here: https://collab.ucsd.edu/display/RESUP/UCSD+Research+Cluster%3A+User+Guide#UCSDResearchCluster:UserGuide-BackgroundExecution/Long-RunningJobs","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":60,"length":140}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"","data":{"can_edit":1,"command_name":"","description":null,"guid":"47BE936D341F11EE9D4302C0B41BC903","name":"launch-scipy-ml.sh -m 63 -c 7 -b","os_name":null,"os_version":null}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"8EEEEC9043D911EB9E300A58A9FEAC2A","url":"https://collab.ucsd.edu/display/RESUP/UCSD+Research+Cluster%3A+User+Guide#UCSDResearchCluster:UserGuide-BackgroundExecution/Long-RunningJobs"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dqtef","text":"To check how many pods you currently have running on the server, use the command kubectl get pods after logging in. This is also a great way to get the pod names (for pods launched in the background) so that you can access them.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":81,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eanjv","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3iiq9","text":"Note that you can launch as many pods as you like, provided you do not exceed 64GB of total RAM and 8 total cores in your combined total resource allocations for them (each student in our group has 64GB RAM and 8 cores at their disposal).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":238}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"","data":{"can_edit":1,"command_name":"","description":null,"guid":"47BE93B1341F11EE9D4302C0B41BC903","name":"kubectl get pods","os_name":null,"os_version":null}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"d75u8","text":"Now that you've launched a pod, you can run whatever lines of code you need to install programs and their dependencies, run programs, etc (all from the command line)! If you're interested in using MitoFinder, that program and all of its dependencies are already pre-installed on the cluster for you. You should see them in your home directory (on the server) if you use the command ls to view the contents of your directory after launching a pod.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":382,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"cb3js","text":"To access a different pod or one you have running in the background, you'll need the pod name (see above) and the kubesh command. Once you've \"entered\" the pod with kubesh, you can run processes/programs from the command line as normal. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":114,"length":6},{"style":"bold","offset":165,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"70to8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4jhhj","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"dgcci","text":"Pod names will consist of your AD login and a 4-6 digit number (12345 is just an example), separated by a hyphen. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":114}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":1,"command_name":"","description":null,"guid":"47BE93F1341F11EE9D4302C0B41BC903","name":"kubesh adlogin-12345","os_name":null,"os_version":null}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"evsna","text":"To stop running a pod and return the resources allocated to it to the cluster, use kubectl delete pod and the appropriate pod name. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":83,"length":19}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"64n3b","text":"Please note: This does NOT delete ANY of your data! It simply ends any processes you have running and returns the memory and cores allocated to the cluster (analogous to quitting a program after saving; any files created already will have automatically saved on the cluster). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":13,"length":38},{"style":"italic","offset":13,"length":38},{"style":"italic","offset":71,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2m7ag","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"m9hp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"87b6b","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"1v736","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"asb07","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"306h1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ekr2n","text":"Please remember to ALWAYS DELETE PODS WHEN YOU'VE FINISHED running your processes so that those resources can be allocated to other users on the cluster. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":19,"length":39},{"style":"italic","offset":19,"length":40}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cclqa","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"572j9","text":"See the User Guide for detailed information about time limits: https://collab.ucsd.edu/display/RESUP/UCSD+Research+Cluster%3A+User+Guide#UCSDResearchCluster:UserGuide-ContainerRunTimeLimits","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":63,"length":126}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"","data":{"can_edit":1,"command_name":"","description":null,"guid":"47BE9431341F11EE9D4302C0B41BC903","name":"kubectl delete pod adlogin-12345","os_name":null,"os_version":null}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":131,"offset":0,"style":"italic"},{"length":51,"offset":135,"style":"italic"},{"length":4,"offset":131,"style":"bold"}],"key":"3rfs1","text":"Note: If you are only running a single pod (no pods in the background) you can also delete  it (terminate the processes) using the exit command (you do not need to specify the pod name).","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"2":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"4A82348943D911EB9E300A58A9FEAC2A","url":"https://collab.ucsd.edu/display/RESUP/UCSD+Research+Cluster%3A+User+Guide#UCSDResearchCluster:UserGuide-ContainerRunTimeLimits"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7h37f","text":"To download a file from the server, use get with the path of the file you want on the server. If you don't specify a download location (where you want it to go), it will appear in your home directory on your computer (or whatever your default working directory is). You can specify a location on your computer where you want the file to go by adding the absolute path to that folder on your computer after the path to the file you want on the server, as you see below.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":40,"length":3},{"style":"italic","offset":79,"length":13},{"style":"italic","offset":400,"length":5}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4hdsg","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7bo8l","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2qfk7","text":"If you'd like to download an entire folder rather than just a single file, add -r to the get command.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":79,"length":3}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a2nsn","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7dnni","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"","data":{"can_edit":1,"command_name":"","description":null,"guid":"47BE9472341F11EE9D4302C0B41BC903","name":"get path/to/file/filename path/to/local/folder","os_name":null,"os_version":null}},"1":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":1,"command_name":"","description":null,"guid":"47C0D609341F11EE9D4302C0B41BC903","name":"get -r path/to/folder","os_name":null,"os_version":null}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"crv8r","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8gut6","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3f4dk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"44oud","text":"Regardless of what you'd like to check, you'll need to make sure you're logged into the server:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9ilss","text":"If you're logged out of the server, log back in with ssh (see step 9). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fd2ib","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":73,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"6l1lg","text":"There are multiple ways to check the progress of processes you're running: you can check what pods are active, you can check what processes are currently active, and you can view the log files of processes you're running.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1sm8b","text":"To check active processes: ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":27}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1kl37","text":"(You may want to do this to check what stage an analysis is in, i.e. which programs are running at the present moment)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":118}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fg3oo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eu00s","text":"You will need to move into the active pod (if applicable) in order to view processes active within it. To do this, use the kubesh command with the pod name (use the kubectl get pods command from above if you can't remember the name of the pod you would like to check). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":123,"length":7},{"style":"bold","offset":165,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7qo0t","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4839j","text":"Once you're in your active pod, use the htop command to view current activity in that pod (similar to the Activity Monitor on a Mac). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":40,"length":4}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4varn","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"fogiq","text":"If your Terminal window is small, you'll need to expand it (at least half your screen) to easily see the programs that are running. A list of actively running programs can be found at the bottom of the window, past all of the bars. In the \"Command\" column you'll see green text that lists the name of each command running (note that this includes the absolute path to the file, so if you're running MitoFinder, look for commands with paths into the MitoFinder folder).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9qdu3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f2ct","text":"You can quit the activity monitor window by pressing q or F10.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":53,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"","data":{"can_edit":1,"command_name":"","description":null,"guid":"47BE93F1341F11EE9D4302C0B41BC903","name":"kubesh adlogin-12345","os_name":null,"os_version":null}},"1":{"type":"command","mutability":"","data":{"can_edit":1,"command_name":"","description":"view activity in local environment","guid":"47C0D5C6341F11EE9D4302C0B41BC903","name":"htop","os_name":null,"os_version":null}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dlift","text":"To check log files:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":18}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bvev6","text":"(This is a quick way to view files in your terminal window without downloading them. You can edit files in this way too, so if you're just interested in checking the progress of a log file, be careful not to make any edits)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":134},{"style":"italic","offset":138,"length":85}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3df0d","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c9krn","text":"Once you're logged in (ssh), use the ls command to view the files in your current working directory. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":37,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3qlu","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"168vn","text":"Running the above command will print a list of all the files/directories in your working directory on the cluster. To view one, you'll use the command view. If you're looking for a mitofinder log, you'll be looking for a file that is some variant of \"MitoFinder.log\"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":151,"length":4}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8k82t","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"2me8u","text":"Running the above command will make the file contents visible in your terminal window (scroll up and down to view all contents, remember to be careful not to make any edits if you are viewing an in-progress file). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5ome0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3vce5","text":"When you're ready to leave the view window and return to your normal terminal window, run the :q! command to quit the viewer (this will not quit the terminal). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":94,"length":3}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5fedh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2344b","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"1q8d9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"","data":{"can_edit":1,"command_name":"","description":"list files and directories","guid":"47C0D4F1341F11EE9D4302C0B41BC903","name":"ls","os_name":null,"os_version":null}},"1":{"type":"command","mutability":"","data":{"can_edit":1,"command_name":"","description":"view and/or edit a file","guid":"47C0D53B341F11EE9D4302C0B41BC903","name":"view name_of_file.log","os_name":null,"os_version":null}},"2":{"type":"command","mutability":"","data":{"can_edit":1,"command_name":"","description":"quit the file viewer/editor","guid":"47C0D583341F11EE9D4302C0B41BC903","name":":q!","os_name":null,"os_version":null}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"67uvn","text":"To check active pods: ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":22}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cuh1s","text":"(You may want to do this as a quick check to make sure your pods are still active if you logged out/lost connection or it's been a while since you started a background pod)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":172}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"989di","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1i8g3","text":"Once you're logged in to the server (ssh), use the get pods command to view active pods.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":51,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"426i1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e0l6p","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"a4j1q","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c1b6j","text":"This will print a list of active pods to your terminal. Active pods should say \"Running\" next to the pod name. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"","data":{"can_edit":1,"command_name":"","description":null,"guid":"47BE93B1341F11EE9D4302C0B41BC903","name":"kubectl get pods","os_name":null,"os_version":null}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"a2a81","text":"MitoFinder can be pre-loaded onto the cluster using Docker (image including MitoFinder and all of its dependencies already created). To access the Docker image, add the following code to your launch script when you launch your pod:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2sv7u","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aids7","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"63tif","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4dd4m","text":"If you choose to run your pod in the background (as in Step 13), your launch script will look something like this:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":55,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9c87u","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2s46n","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"2mqmb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":1,"command_name":"","description":"Add to launch script to use MitoFinder","guid":"47C254CD341F11EE9D4302C0B41BC903","name":"-i amoxley/mitofinder:2020.10.28-3","os_name":null,"os_version":null}},"1":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":1,"command_name":"","description":"Launch a pod (with MitoFinder) that will use no more than 63GB of memory, 7 cores, and will run in the background","guid":"47C25513341F11EE9D4302C0B41BC903","name":"launch-scipy-ml.sh -i amoxley/mitofinder:2020.10.28-3 -m 63 -c 7 -b","os_name":null,"os_version":null}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"a9c6u","text":"NOTE: If you've launched your pod in the background (as in the example above) you will need to navigate into it in order to run MitoFinder.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":5},{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":5},{"style":"italic","offset":6,"length":133}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7ta0t","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d2bjg","text":"To do this, use the command kubesh and the pod name as in Step 15 (pod name will be auto-generated and printed to your terminal once the pod launches successfully). For example, your code will look something like this (pod name will be specific to you):","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":28,"length":6},{"style":"bold","offset":58,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3s8c9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d3bq","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bmuac","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":1,"command_name":"","description":null,"guid":"47BE93F1341F11EE9D4302C0B41BC903","name":"kubesh adlogin-12345","os_name":null,"os_version":null}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"b8tdc","text":"Once you've navigated into your pod, you can run MitoFinder as normal. The absolute path to the program is /opt/MitoFinder/mitofinder so you can use that to call the program as you normally would. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":107,"length":27}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cj2nv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ce186","text":"Consider the example below, but remember to customize the MitoFinder settings to your specifications for your project (e.g. metaspades vs megahit, memory limits, etc). Do not simply run this code without first understanding which settings you need for your assembly. The output folder with results will appear in your home directory on the cluster.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":32,"length":68}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"en6jm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fesqd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9j1hg","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"eeaim","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fdfil","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"drib5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":1,"command_name":"","description":"Example code for running MitoFinder. Remember to provide an output folder name (samplename_1 in this example), and the fq.gz-format files for your trimmed reads, as well as a .gb-format reference genomes file. This example is set to run with a maximum of 63GB of RAM and 7 cores.","guid":"47C25557341F11EE9D4302C0B41BC903","name":"/opt/MitoFinder/mitofinder --megahit -t mitfi -j samplename_1 -1 sampletrimmed_P1.fq.gz -2 sampletrimmed_P2.fq.gz -r reference_mitogenomes_file.gb -o 5 -m 63 -p 7","os_name":null,"os_version":null}}}}

title: Research Cluster: Spineless Genomics
